source.query: trap bar romanian deadlift muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Trap Bar Romanian Deadlift (RDL) is a hip-hinge movement primarily targeting the posterior chain (glutes, hamstrings, lower back/erector spinae), but also involves quads, traps, lats, core, and grip. The movement pattern involves a controlled hip hinge with a slight knee bend, keeping the back flat and core tight, moving the bar vertically down the thighs and back up by driving the hips forward and squeezing the glutes, minimizing spinal rounding for a gentler back alternative to traditional RDLs. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
This video demonstrates the correct form for a Trap Bar Romanian Deadlift: 
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: Glutes, Hamstrings, Erector Spinae (Lower Back). 
• Secondary/Stabilizers: Quadriceps (more than traditional RDLs), Traps, Lats, Core, Forearms/Grip, Adductors, Calves. [1, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Pattern (Hip Hinge) 

1. Setup: Stand inside the trap bar with feet hip-width apart, knees slightly bent, shoulders back and down, chest up, and a flat back, holding the bar at your midline. 
2. Descent (Hinge): Push hips backward, keeping the slight knee bend, lowering the bar vertically along your thighs towards the floor (stopping around shin level). 
3. Ascent (Extend): Drive hips forward, squeeze glutes to return to standing, maintaining a flat back and neutral spine. [2, 5, 9, 10, 11]  

Key Characteristics 

• Back-Friendly: The center of gravity with the trap bar reduces lower back strain compared to barbell RDLs. 
• Posterior Chain Focus: Excellent for developing the entire backside of the body. 
• Compound Movement: Works multiple muscle groups for functional strength. [2, 3, 5, 8]  

**Citations:**
